PROOF OF NODE 1.4.4: UV DIVERGENCE ANALYSIS OF THE INTERACTION DIFFERENCE

We analyze each term in the decomposition of DeltaV_eps(phi) (established in Node 1.4.3) as eps -> 0 under the Phi^4_3 measure mu on T^3. We work on the three-dimensional torus T^3 with dimension d = 3.

=== Functional-Analytic Preliminaries ===

We recall the key regularity facts for the Phi^4_3 field theory on T^3 (d=3).

(R1) Under the GFF mu_0 (and also under the Phi^4_3 measure mu, which lives in the same Besov-Hoelder regularity class), the random field phi belongs mu-a.s. to the Hoelder-Besov space C^{-1/2-delta}(T^3) for every delta > 0. This is the standard regularity of the GFF in d=3: the covariance kernel C(x,y) = (-Delta + m^2)^{-1}(x,y) has a singularity |x-y|^{-(d-2)} = |x-y|^{-1} in d=3, placing phi in C^{-d/2+1-delta} = C^{-1/2-delta}. [Ref: Hairer (2014), Sec. 10; Gubinelli-Imkeller-Perkowski (2015), Sec. 4.]

(R2) The Wick powers :phi^k: are well-defined distributions (in the sense of Schwartz) on T^3 under mu, with the following regularities:
  - :phi: = phi in C^{-1/2-delta}(T^3),
  - :phi^2: in C^{-1-delta}(T^3),
  - :phi^3: in C^{-3/2-delta}(T^3),
for every delta > 0. These regularities follow from the general principle that Wick-ordering a k-th power of a field of regularity alpha yields a distribution of regularity k*alpha (heuristically), made rigorous by regularity structures (Hairer 2014, Thm 10.7) and paracontrolled distributions (Gubinelli-Imkeller-Perkowski 2015, Thm 1.1). The precise statement is that :phi^k: belongs to C^{k(-1/2-delta')+delta''} for suitable delta', delta'' > 0, which for k=2 gives C^{-1-delta} and for k=3 gives C^{-3/2-delta}.

(R3) Mollification and convergence. Let rho_eps be a standard mollifier on T^3 and f_eps = rho_eps * f for any distribution f. Then:
  - If f in C^alpha(T^3), then f_eps -> f in C^alpha(T^3) as eps -> 0.
  - If g in C^inf(T^3), then g_eps -> g in C^beta(T^3) for every beta > 0 (in fact in C^inf).
  - The Wick powers :phi_eps^k:_{C_eps} of the mollified field converge: :phi_eps^k:_{C_eps} -> :phi^k: in C^{k(-1/2)-delta}(T^3) as eps -> 0, mu-a.s. and in L^p(mu) for all p >= 1. This is a fundamental result of the regularity structures / paracontrolled theory.

(R4) Duality pairing. For alpha > 0, the duality pairing <f, g> = integral_{T^3} f(x) g(x) dx is well-defined and continuous as a bilinear map C^alpha(T^3) x C^{-alpha+delta}(T^3) -> R for any delta > 0 with alpha - delta > 0. More precisely, if f in C^alpha and g in C^{-beta} with alpha > beta, then |<f, g>| <= C ||f||_{C^alpha} ||g||_{C^{-beta}}, and the pairing is jointly continuous.

=== PART (a): Convergence of the Cubic Term ===

Claim: As eps -> 0, integral_{T^3} psi_eps(x) :phi_eps^3(x):_{C_eps} dx -> integral_{T^3} psi(x) :phi^3(x): dx, where convergence holds mu-a.s. and in L^p(mu) for all p >= 1.

Proof of Part (a):

We write the cubic term as the duality pairing <psi_eps, :phi_eps^3:_{C_eps}>. We must show this converges to <psi, :phi^3:>.

Step (a.1): Regularity of the test function. Since psi in C^inf(T^3), we have psi in C^alpha(T^3) for every alpha > 0. In particular, psi in C^{3/2+2delta}(T^3) for any delta > 0. Similarly, psi_eps = rho_eps * psi in C^inf(T^3), and psi_eps -> psi in C^beta(T^3) for every beta > 0. In particular, ||psi_eps - psi||_{C^{3/2+2delta}} -> 0 as eps -> 0.

Step (a.2): Regularity of the Wick cube. By (R2) and (R3), :phi_eps^3:_{C_eps} -> :phi^3: in C^{-3/2-delta}(T^3), mu-a.s. and in L^p(mu) for all p >= 1.

Step (a.3): The duality pairing is well-defined and continuous. We apply (R4) with alpha = 3/2 + 2*delta and beta = 3/2 + delta. Since alpha > beta (as 2*delta > delta for delta > 0), the pairing C^{3/2+2delta} x C^{-3/2-delta} -> R is continuous. Explicitly:

|<psi_eps, :phi_eps^3:_{C_eps}> - <psi, :phi^3:>|
  = |<psi_eps, :phi_eps^3:_{C_eps}> - <psi, :phi_eps^3:_{C_eps}> + <psi, :phi_eps^3:_{C_eps}> - <psi, :phi^3:>|
  <= |<psi_eps - psi, :phi_eps^3:_{C_eps}>| + |<psi, :phi_eps^3:_{C_eps} - :phi^3:>|.

For the first term: by (R4),
  |<psi_eps - psi, :phi_eps^3:_{C_eps}>| <= C ||psi_eps - psi||_{C^{3/2+2delta}} ||:phi_eps^3:_{C_eps}||_{C^{-3/2-delta}}.
The first factor -> 0 by Step (a.1). The second factor is bounded (uniformly in eps) since :phi_eps^3:_{C_eps} converges in C^{-3/2-delta}, hence is bounded in that norm for eps small enough.

For the second term: by (R4),
  |<psi, :phi_eps^3:_{C_eps} - :phi^3:>| <= C ||psi||_{C^{3/2+2delta}} ||:phi_eps^3:_{C_eps} - :phi^3:||_{C^{-3/2-delta}}.
The first factor is a fixed finite constant. The second factor -> 0 by Step (a.2).

Therefore <psi_eps, :phi_eps^3:_{C_eps}> -> <psi, :phi^3:> as eps -> 0. The convergence holds mu-a.s. (since both (a.1) and (a.2) hold mu-a.s.) and in L^p(mu) for all p >= 1 (since :phi_eps^3:_{C_eps} converges in L^p(mu; C^{-3/2-delta}) by the regularity theory).

Conclusion for (a): The cubic term -4 lambda <psi_eps, :phi_eps^3:_{C_eps}> converges to -4 lambda <psi, :phi^3:>, which is a FINITE, well-defined random variable under mu. NO UV divergence arises. QED (a).

=== PART (b): Convergence of the Quadratic Term ===

Claim: As eps -> 0, integral_{T^3} psi_eps^2(x) :phi_eps^2(x):_{C_eps} dx -> integral_{T^3} psi^2(x) :phi^2(x): dx, where convergence holds mu-a.s. and in L^p(mu) for all p >= 1.

Proof of Part (b):

The argument is strictly analogous to Part (a), but with better regularity margins.

Step (b.1): The test function psi^2 in C^inf(T^3) (since psi in C^inf and C^inf is an algebra). Hence psi^2 in C^{1+2delta}(T^3) for any delta > 0, and psi_eps^2 -> psi^2 in C^{1+2delta}(T^3).

Step (b.2): By (R2) and (R3), :phi_eps^2:_{C_eps} -> :phi^2: in C^{-1-delta}(T^3), mu-a.s. and in L^p(mu).

Step (b.3): The pairing C^{1+2delta} x C^{-1-delta} -> R is continuous by (R4), since 1+2*delta > 1+delta for delta > 0. The estimate proceeds identically to Part (a):

|<psi_eps^2, :phi_eps^2:_{C_eps}> - <psi^2, :phi^2:>|
  <= |<psi_eps^2 - psi^2, :phi_eps^2:_{C_eps}>| + |<psi^2, :phi_eps^2:_{C_eps} - :phi^2:>|
  -> 0 as eps -> 0.

Note: The regularity margin is even more favorable here than in Part (a). The Wick square :phi^2: in C^{-1-delta} has better regularity than the Wick cube :phi^3: in C^{-3/2-delta}, so the pairing with the smooth test function psi^2 has a larger positive gap (1+2*delta) - (1+delta) = delta > 0.

Conclusion for (b): The quadratic term 6 lambda <psi_eps^2, :phi_eps^2:_{C_eps}> converges to 6 lambda <psi^2, :phi^2:>, which is FINITE. NO UV divergence arises. QED (b).

=== PART (c): Linear Term — Convergence and Divergence ===

The linear contribution from DeltaV_eps consists of two terms (from Node 1.4.3):
  (c.i) -4 lambda <psi_eps^3, phi_eps>, and
  (c.ii) -2 delta_m_eps^2 <psi_eps, phi_eps>.
We analyze each separately.

--- Part (c.i): Convergence of <psi_eps^3, phi_eps> ---

Claim: <psi_eps^3, phi_eps> -> <psi^3, phi> as eps -> 0, and the limit is finite mu-a.s.

Proof: Since psi in C^inf, we have psi^3 in C^inf (C^inf is closed under multiplication). In particular psi^3 in C^{1/2+2delta}(T^3) for any delta > 0, and psi_eps^3 -> psi^3 in C^{1/2+2delta}(T^3). By (R1), phi in C^{-1/2-delta}(T^3) mu-a.s., and phi_eps -> phi in C^{-1/2-delta}(T^3). The duality pairing C^{1/2+2delta} x C^{-1/2-delta} -> R is continuous by (R4) (since 1/2+2*delta > 1/2+delta for delta > 0). The same triangle-inequality argument as in Parts (a)-(b) gives:

|<psi_eps^3, phi_eps> - <psi^3, phi>|
  <= |<psi_eps^3 - psi^3, phi_eps>| + |<psi^3, phi_eps - phi>|
  -> 0 as eps -> 0, mu-a.s.

Hence -4 lambda <psi_eps^3, phi_eps> -> -4 lambda <psi^3, phi>, which is finite. No divergence.

--- Part (c.ii): Divergence of delta_m_eps^2 <psi_eps, phi_eps> ---

Claim: 2 delta_m_eps^2 <psi_eps, phi_eps> diverges as eps -> 0 (assuming psi is not identically zero and <psi, phi> is non-zero mu-a.s.).

Proof: We analyze the two factors separately.

Factor 1: <psi_eps, phi_eps> -> <psi, phi>. By the same argument as in (c.i) (with psi in place of psi^3), we have psi in C^inf subset C^{1/2+2delta} and phi in C^{-1/2-delta}, so <psi_eps, phi_eps> -> <psi, phi>. The limit <psi, phi> is a well-defined finite random variable under mu (it is a continuous linear functional of phi). Moreover, for psi not identically zero, <psi, phi> is a non-degenerate Gaussian random variable under mu_0 (and has a non-degenerate, though non-Gaussian, distribution under mu), so <psi, phi> is nonzero mu-a.s.

Factor 2: delta_m_eps^2 -> +infinity. The mass counterterm is given by:
  delta_m_eps^2 = c lambda^2 sum_{k in Z^3} (rho_hat_eps(k))^2 / (|k|^2 + m^2)^2 + O(lambda^3),
where rho_hat_eps(k) = rho_hat(eps k) is the Fourier multiplier of the mollifier. The leading term is the second-order Feynman diagram (the "tadpole" or "sunset" contribution at zero external momentum). In d=3, this sum diverges logarithmically:
  delta_m_eps^2 ~ c' lambda^2 log(1/eps) as eps -> 0,
where c' > 0 is an explicit constant depending on the mollifier and the mass m. This logarithmic divergence is the standard mass renormalization in Phi^4_3 (see Hairer 2014, Sec. 10.5; Barashkov-Gubinelli 2020, Sec. 2.3).

Product: Since <psi_eps, phi_eps> -> <psi, phi> (a finite, generically nonzero random variable) and delta_m_eps^2 ~ c' lambda^2 log(1/eps) -> +infinity, the product
  2 delta_m_eps^2 <psi_eps, phi_eps> ~ 2 c' lambda^2 log(1/eps) * <psi, phi>
diverges to +/- infinity (depending on the sign of <psi, phi>, which varies from sample to sample).

Crucially, this divergent term is LINEAR in phi: it equals 2 delta_m_eps^2 times the linear functional phi |-> <psi_eps, phi_eps> = <rho_eps * psi, rho_eps * phi> (which converges to the linear functional phi |-> <psi, phi>). It is therefore a FIELD-DEPENDENT divergence, meaning it cannot be absorbed into normalization alone. It must be handled by the exponential tilt / renormalization mechanism in Nodes 1.5 and 1.6.

Conclusion for (c): The linear contribution decomposes into a convergent piece (-4 lambda <psi^3, phi>, finite) and a divergent piece (-2 delta_m_eps^2 <psi, phi>, diverging as log(1/eps)). The divergent piece is field-dependent (linear in phi). QED (c).

=== PART (d): Constant Terms ===

The constant (field-independent) contributions from DeltaV_eps are (from Node 1.4.3):
  (d.i) lambda ||psi_eps||_4^4, and
  (d.ii) delta_m_eps^2 ||psi_eps||_2^2.

--- Part (d.i): lambda ||psi_eps||_4^4 ---

Claim: lambda ||psi_eps||_4^4 -> lambda ||psi||_4^4 < infinity.

Proof: Since psi in C^inf(T^3) subset L^4(T^3), and psi_eps = rho_eps * psi -> psi in every L^p(T^3) (indeed in C^inf), we have ||psi_eps||_4^4 -> ||psi||_4^4 by continuity of the L^4 norm. The limit is finite since psi is smooth on the compact torus T^3. This term is field-independent (it depends only on the fixed, deterministic function psi). No divergence.

--- Part (d.ii): delta_m_eps^2 ||psi_eps||_2^2 ---

Claim: delta_m_eps^2 ||psi_eps||_2^2 diverges as eps -> 0 (for psi not identically zero), but is field-independent.

Proof: ||psi_eps||_2^2 -> ||psi||_2^2 > 0 (since psi is smooth, nonzero, on compact T^3). Meanwhile delta_m_eps^2 ~ c' lambda^2 log(1/eps) -> +infinity. Therefore the product delta_m_eps^2 ||psi_eps||_2^2 -> +infinity.

However, this divergent quantity is a CONSTANT — it does not depend on the stochastic field phi at all. It is a deterministic real number that diverges as eps -> 0. In the Radon-Nikodym derivative R_eps = exp(Psi_eps), this term contributes a multiplicative factor exp(-delta_m_eps^2 ||psi_eps||_2^2) (with a sign determined by the full decomposition in Node 1.5). Since R_eps must satisfy E_{mu_eps}[R_eps] = 1 (it is a Radon-Nikodym derivative), the normalization constant Z_eps = E_{mu_eps}[exp(Psi_eps^{ren} + L_eps)] absorbs this divergent constant. The divergence of the constant is compensated by the normalization — this is the standard mechanism by which field-independent infinities are removed in QFT.

Conclusion for (d): lambda ||psi||_4^4 is finite. delta_m_eps^2 ||psi||_2^2 diverges but is field-independent, hence absorbed into normalization. QED (d).

=== CONCLUSION: Classification of UV Divergences ===

Assembling all four parts, we classify each term in DeltaV_eps by its eps -> 0 behavior:

  CONVERGENT and FIELD-DEPENDENT:
    (a) -4 lambda <psi_eps, :phi_eps^3:_{C_eps}> -> -4 lambda <psi, :phi^3:> (cubic in phi)
    (b) +6 lambda <psi_eps^2, :phi_eps^2:_{C_eps}> -> +6 lambda <psi^2, :phi^2:> (quadratic in phi)
    (c.i) -4 lambda <psi_eps^3, phi_eps> -> -4 lambda <psi^3, phi> (linear in phi)

  CONVERGENT and FIELD-INDEPENDENT:
    (d.i) lambda ||psi_eps||_4^4 -> lambda ||psi||_4^4

  DIVERGENT and FIELD-DEPENDENT:
    (c.ii) -2 delta_m_eps^2 <psi_eps, phi_eps> ~ -2 c' lambda^2 log(1/eps) <psi, phi> -> -infinity * <psi, phi> (linear in phi)

  DIVERGENT and FIELD-INDEPENDENT:
    (d.ii) delta_m_eps^2 ||psi_eps||_2^2 ~ c' lambda^2 log(1/eps) ||psi||_2^2 -> +infinity (constant)

The ONLY UV-divergent contribution that depends on the field phi is the linear term:
  L_eps(phi) = 2 delta_m_eps^2 <psi_eps, phi_eps>,
which diverges as c' lambda^2 log(1/eps) * <psi, phi>.

All Wick-power pairings (cubic and quadratic) converge because:
  (1) The Wick powers :phi_eps^k:_{C_eps} converge in C^{-k/2-delta} (regularity structures theory);
  (2) The smooth test functions psi, psi^2 provide sufficient positive regularity for the duality pairing;
  (3) The duality C^{alpha} x C^{-beta} -> R is continuous whenever alpha > beta.

The divergent field-independent constant delta_m_eps^2 ||psi||_2^2 is absorbed into the normalization of the Radon-Nikodym derivative (as will be shown in Node 1.5).

This completes the proof of Node 1.4.4. QED.

=== References ===
[1] Hairer, M. (2014). A theory of regularity structures. Inventiones mathematicae, 198(2), 269-504. [Regularity of Wick powers :phi^k: under Phi^4_3; Theorem 10.7]
[2] Gubinelli, M., Imkeller, P., Perkowski, N. (2015). Paracontrolled distributions and singular PDEs. Forum of Mathematics, Pi, 3, e6. [Paracontrolled approach; Theorem 1.1]
[3] Barashkov, N., Gubinelli, M. (2020). A variational method for Phi^4_3. Duke Math. J., 169(17), 3339-3415. [Variational construction confirming regularity; mass counterterm asymptotics]
[4] Barashkov, N., Gubinelli, M. (2021). On the variational method for Euclidean quantum fields in infinite volume. arXiv:2112.05562. [Sub-Gaussian tails for the Phi^4_3 measure]
